case_name: Manager, Hotel Imperial, New Delhi v. Chief Commissioner, Delhi & Ors.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 291 of 1956 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated November 25, 1955, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi, in Civil Writ Application No. 189-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 291 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 25, 1955, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi, in Civil Writ Application No. 189-D of 1955.

facts.text: The appeal comes before the Supreme Court on a certificate granted by the Punjab High Court under Art. 133(1)(a) and (c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal companyes before us on a certificate granted by the Punjab High Court under, Art. 133  1   a  and  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: The appellant is the manager, Hotel Imperial, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manager, Hotel Imperial, New Delhi  here in after called the hotel  while the respondents are the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, the Additional Industrial Tribunal, Delhi , and the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi , Chandni Chowk, Delhi.

facts.text: Respondents are the Chief Commissioner, Delhi (No.1), the Additional Industrial Tribunal, Delhi (No.2), and the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi, Chandni Chowk, Delhi (No.3).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manager, Hotel Imperial, New Delhi  here in after called the hotel  while the respondents are the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, the Additional Industrial Tribunal, Delhi , and the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi , Chandni Chowk, Delhi. The main companytesting respondent is respondent No. 3  here- inafter called the union .

facts.text: A dispute arose between the hotel and its workmen in October 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A dispute arose between the hotel and its workmen in October 1955.

facts.text: The dispute was referred to an Industrial Tribunal on October 12, 1955, by the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: It was referred to an Industrial Tribunal on October 12, 1955, by the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

facts.text: The order of reference states that an industrial dispute exists between the management of the Hotel Imperial, New Delhi and its workmen as represented by the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi, Chandni Chowk, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas from a report submitted by the Director of Industries and Labour, Delhi under s. 12  4  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 as amended, it appears that an industrial dispute exists between the management of the Hotel Imperial, New Delhi and its workmen as represented by the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi, Chandni Chowk, Delhi

facts.text: Soon after the reference, the hotel filed a writ application in the Punjab High Court challenging the order of reference.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the hotel filed a writ application in the Punjab High Court challenging the order of reference on a variety of grounds.

facts.text: The writ application was dismissed by the Punjab High Court on November 25, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The writ application was heard by the High Court and dismissed on November 25, 1955.

facts.text: The hotel applied for leave to appeal to the Supreme Court, which was granted on January 13, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The hotel then applied for leave to appeal to this Court, which was granted on January 13, 1956.

facts.text: The hotel obtained stay of the proceedings before the Additional Industrial Tribunal from the Supreme Court on February 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The hotel obtained stay of the proceedings before the Additional Industrial Tribunal from this Court on February 27, 1956.

facts.text: The hotel decided to dismiss a large number of workmen on October 7, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: it went to this length that the hotel decided to dismiss a large number of workmen on October 7, 1955.

facts.text: The hotel contends that the reference is incompetent because the union could not be made a party to the reference under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the main companytention on behalf of the hotel is -that the reference is incompetent and two grounds have been urged in support of it namely,  1  the union companyld number be made a party to the reference under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,

facts.text: The hotel contends that the reference was vague as it did not indicate how many of the 480 workers of thirty different categories working in the hotel were involved in the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: 2  the reference was vague, as it does number indicate how many of the 480 workers of thirty different categories working in the hotel were involved in the dispute.

facts.text: There are 480 workers of thirty different categories working in the hotel.

anchor.surface_text: how many of the 480 workers of thirty different categories working in the hotel were involved in the dispute.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that there is no force in the grounds of attack on the reference.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is numberforce in these grounds of attack.

facts.text: An industrial dispute exists between the hotel and its workmen with respect to the terms of employment or conditions of labour.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be denied on the facts of this case that there was a dispute between the hotel and its workmen and it went to this length that the hotel decided to dismiss a large number of workmen on October 7, 1955. It is also undoubted that the dispute was With respect to the terms of employment Qr companyditions of labour of the workmen.

facts.text: The Chief Commissioner had power under s. 10(1) of the Act to make the reference.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Commissioner would therefore have power under s. 10  1  of the Act to make a reference of the dispute to a tribunal for adjudication.

facts.text: The two parties to the dispute are the management of the hotel and the workmen employed in the hotel.

anchor.surface_text: The two parties to the dispute are clearly indicated, namely,  1  the employer which is the management of the hotel and  2  the workmen employed in the hotel.

facts.text: The addition of words 'as represented by the Hotel Workers Union' in the order of reference is merely for convenience.

anchor.surface_text: The addition of the words as represented by the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi, Chandni Chowk, Delhi was merely for the sake of companyvenience so that the tribunal may know to whom it should give numberice when proceeding to deal with the reference.

facts.text: The appeal is dismissed with costs to respondent No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in this appeal and it is hereby dismissed with companyts to respondent No. 3.
under, Art. 133  1   a  and  c  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The reference is incompetent because the union could not be made a party to the reference under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: the union could not be made a party to the reference under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,  hereinafter called the Act  and  2  the reference was vague,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: know to whom it should give numberice when proceeding to deal with the reference. That however did number preclude the workmen, if they wanted to be

arguments.court_reasoning: Objection is mere technicality; words added for convenience of notice; does not affect competence; s.36 entitles workmen to union representation; union served through officer

arguments.claim: The reference is incompetent because it was vague as it did not indicate how many of the 480 workers of thirty different categories working in the hotel were involved in the dispute

anchor.surface_text: 2  the reference was vague, as it did not indicate how many of the 480 workers of thirty different categories working in the hotel were involved in the dispute.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nion of His Excellency the Governor of Madras, it is necessary to refer the said industrial dispute for adjudication Thereafter followed the order of

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to specify number of workmen in general disputes re terms/conditions; only desirable for specific dismissals; reference specifies parties and nature; less vague than upheld precedent

arguments.claim: An industrial dispute exists between the hotel and its workmen with respect to the terms of employment or conditions of labour, falling within s.2(k) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be denied on the facts of this case that there was a dispute between the hotel and its workmen and it went to this length that the hotel decided to dismiss a large number of workmen on October 7, 1955. It is also undoubted that the dispute was With respect to the terms of employment Qr conditions of labour of the workmen.

arguments.claim: The Chief Commissioner had power under s.10(1) of the Act to refer the dispute to the tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Commissioner would therefore have power under s. 10  1  of the Act to make a reference of the dispute to a tribunal for adjudication.

arguments.claim: The two parties to the dispute are clearly indicated as the management of the hotel and the workmen employed in the hotel

anchor.surface_text: The two parties to the dispute are clearly indicated, namely,  1  the employer which is the management of the hotel and  2  the workmen employed in the hotel.

arguments.claim: The addition of words 'as represented by the Hotel Workers Union...' is merely for convenience so tribunal knows whom to give notice

anchor.surface_text: The addition of the words as represented by the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi, Chandni Chowk, Delhi was merely for the sake of convenience so that the tribunal may know to whom it should give notice when proceeding to deal with the reference.

arguments.claim: Section 36 entitles workmen party to dispute to be represented by trade union officer, so reference mentioning union does not make it incompetent

anchor.surface_text: Section 36 of the Act provides that a workman who is party to a dispute shall be entitled to be represented in any proceeding under the Act by  a  an officer of a trade union of which he is a member, or  b  an officer of a federation of trade unions to which the trade union of which he is a member is affiliated or  c  where the workmen is not a member of any trade union, by an officer of any trade union connected with, or by any other workman employed in, the industry in which the workman is employed.

arguments.claim: Reference is not rendered incompetent by technicality of mentioning union instead of officer, as union served through officer who represents

anchor.surface_text: The fact therefore that in the order of reference the quoted words were added for the sake of convenience as to where the notice to the workmen should be sent would not in our opinion make the reference incompetent. The objection further is that even if the workman is entitled to be represented by an officer of a trade union of which he is a member, the reference in this case does not mention any officer of the trade union, but mentions the union itself.

arguments.claim: For general disputes relating to terms of employment or conditions of labour, it is unnecessary to specify number or names of particular workmen under s.10

anchor.surface_text: Equally, we see no force in the other ground of attack, namely, that the reference is bad because it does not specify how many of the 480 workmen of thirty different categories were involved in the dispute. It is in our opinion unnecessary for the purposes of s. 10 where the dispute is of a general nature relating to the terms of employment or conditions of labour of a body of workmen, to mention the names of particular workmen who might have been responsible for the dispute.

arguments.claim: Reference under s.10(1) valid despite vagueness, as per precedent in State of Madras v. C.P. Sarathy, where even less specific reference upheld

anchor.surface_text: under s. 10  1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, cannot be held to be invalid merely because it did not specify the disputes or the parties between whom the disputes arose. It was further held that the Government must, of course, have sufficient knowledge of the nature of the dispute to be satisfied that it is an industrial dispute within the meaning of the Act, as, for instance, that it relates to retrenchment or reinstatement.

holdings.text: There was a dispute between the hotel and its workmen with respect to the terms of employment or conditions of labour of the workmen, constituting an industrial dispute under s. 2(k) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be denied on the facts of this case that there was a dispute between the hotel and its workmen and it went to this length that the hotel decided to dismiss a large number of workmen on October 7, 1955. It is also undoubted that the dispute was With respect to the terms of employment Qr companyditions of labour of the workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts establish dispute escalating to planned dismissals, directly concerning terms of employment or conditions of labour as defined in s.2(k).

holdings.text: The Chief Commissioner had power under s. 10(1) of the Act to refer the industrial dispute to the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Commissioner would therefore have power under s. 10  1  of the Act to make a reference of the dispute to a tribunal for adjudication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence of industrial dispute triggers appropriate government's power to refer under s.10(1).

holdings.text: The two parties to the dispute are clearly indicated as the management of the hotel and the workmen employed in the hotel.

anchor.surface_text: The two parties to the dispute are clearly indicated, namely,  1  the employer which is the management of the hotel and  2  the workmen employed in the hotel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order of reference expressly identifies employer and workmen as parties.

holdings.text: The addition of words 'as represented by the Hotel Workers Union' in the reference order was merely for convenience to inform the tribunal whom to notify.

anchor.surface_text: The addition of the words as represented by the Hotel Workers Union, Katra Shahanshahi, Chandni Chowk, Delhi was merely for the sake of companyvenience so that the tribunal may know to whom it should give numberice when proceeding to deal with the reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: facilitates notice without altering parties to dispute.

holdings.text: Mentioning the union as representative does not make the reference incompetent, as it is a technicality that does not affect validity; s.36 allows workmen representation by union officers.

anchor.surface_text: Section 36 of the Act provides that a workman who is party to a dispute shall be entitled to be represented in any proceeding under the Act by  a  an officer of a trade union of which he is a member, or  b  an officer of a federation of trade unions to which the trade union of which he is a member is affiliated or  c  where the workmen is not a member of any trade union, by an officer of any trade union connected with, or by any other workman employed in, the industry in which the workman is employed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.36 permits union representation; naming union aids process without prejudice to rights.

holdings.text: The reference does not become incompetent merely because it names the union rather than a specific officer, as service on union occurs through its officers who represent workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The fact therefore that in the order of reference the quoted words were added for the sake of companyvenience as to where the notice to the workmen should be sent would number in our opinion make the reference incompetent. The objection further is that even if the workman is entitled to be represented by an officer of a trade union of which he is a member, the reference in this case does number mention any officer of the trade union, but mentions the union itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Practical reality: unions act through officers; technical form does not invalidate substance.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary in a reference under s.10 for general disputes on terms of employment or conditions of labour to specify the number or names of particular workmen involved.

anchor.surface_text: Equally, we see numberforce in the other ground of ,attack, namely, that the reference is bad because it does number specify how many of the 480 workmen of thirty different categories were involved in the dispute. It is in our opinion unnecessary for the purposes of s. 10 where the dispute is of a general nature relating to the terms of employment or companyditions of labour of a body of workmen, to mention the names of particular workmen who might have been responsible for the dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes general body disputes from specific individual cases; specification desirable only for latter.

holdings.text: A reference under s.10(1) is not invalid for vagueness if parties and nature of dispute are specified, following State of Madras v. C.P. Sarathy; the present reference is even less vague.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 10  1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, cannot be held to be invalid merely because it did number specify the disputes or the parties between whom the disputes arose. It was further held that the Government must, of companyrse, have sufficient knowledge of the nature of the dispute to be satisfied that it is an industrial dispute within the meaning of the Act, as, for instance, that it relates to retrenchment or reinstatement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent upholds vaguer reference; here parties and nature explicitly stated, satisfying govt knowledge requirement.

holdings.text: There is no force in the appeal challenging the validity of the reference order, and the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in this appeal and it is hereby dismissed with companyts to respondent No. 3.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both grounds of challenge rejected on merits; upholds High Court dismissal.
